definition: Congenital fusion anomaly in which the two kidneys—most often at the **lower poles**—are joined by an **isthmus** crossing the midline. The fused unit tends to sit **low** and is **malrotated**; ascent is commonly limited by the **inferior mesenteric artery (IMA)**.
why\_it\_matters: It’s the **most common renal fusion anomaly** (\~1 in 500; male ≈2:1). Many are incidental, but the abnormal orientation/ureteral course predisposes to **UPJ obstruction → hydronephrosis**, **vesicoureteral reflux**, **recurrent UTIs**, and **nephrolithiasis** (\~36% over a lifetime). Important **syndromic associations** (e.g., Turner syndrome, trisomy 18) and a **higher tumor risk** (e.g., Wilms tumor \~2×; transitional cell carcinoma \~3–4×) make it high‑yield.
how\_youll\_see\_it: Incidentally on prenatal, pediatric, or adult imaging.
Child with recurrent febrile UTIs or hydronephrosis; adolescent/adult with flank pain or stones.
Imaging clues: low‑lying kidneys; **midline isthmus** anterior to aorta/IVC; **malrotation** with **anteriorly oriented renal pelvis** and medially directed lower poles.
problem\_solving: First‑line imaging: **renal/bladder ultrasound** (look for isthmus, hydronephrosis, stones).
Define anatomy/complications: **CT urogram** (or MRI urography) for isthmus position, collecting system, and stones; map **variant vasculature** when surgery is planned.
Obstruction? → **Diuretic renography (MAG3)** for drainage/function; **UPJ obstruction** is most common.
Recurrent febrile UTIs/antenatal hydronephrosis (peds) → **VCUG** to assess **VUR**.

Treat the **complication**, not the fusion: pyeloplasty for significant UPJ obstruction, standard stone pathways (URS/PCNL/ESWL with anatomy‑aware planning), UTI management ± prophylaxis. **Do not divide the isthmus** routinely.
tricks: Embryology pearl: ascent gets **“stuck” under the IMA** (classically around L3–L5).
**Malrotation** is expected → pelvis faces **anteriorly**, calyces often point posterior/medial.
**Syndromes to remember**: **Turner (≈14–20%)**, **trisomy 18**; Down syndrome is less frequent.
Stones are common in adults with HSK (\~**36%**).
HSK is more susceptible to **blunt abdominal trauma** (low, midline position).
exam\_appearance: Short, web‑necked teen with primary amenorrhea and coarctation: ultrasound shows **fused lower poles with midline isthmus** → HSK in **Turner syndrome**.
Toddler with recurrent febrile UTIs and bilateral hydronephrosis: MAG3 shows delayed washout at **UPJ** → HSK with **UPJ obstruction**.
Adult with colicky flank pain and microscopic hematuria: CT shows U‑shaped kidneys crossing midline with proximal ureteral stone.
treatment: Asymptomatic → **observation**; monitor BP, renal function, and complications.
**UPJ obstruction** with impaired drainage → **pyeloplasty** after functional confirmation.
Stones → standard approaches (URS/PCNL/ESWL) tailored to anatomy; note **SWL** may be less effective for certain stones due to clearance issues.
UTIs → guideline‑based treatment; address reflux/obstruction if present.
red\_flags: Child with HSK + new **abdominal mass or gross hematuria** → evaluate for **Wilms tumor**.
Planned aortic/abdominal surgery without imaging → risk of injuring **aberrant renal vessels**; obtain CTA/MRA.
Lower abdominal **blunt trauma** with flank pain/hematuria → consider contrast CT (isthmus/low‑lying kidney injury).
algorithm: Confirm and map anatomy/complications → **CT urogram/MR urogram**; consider **CTA/MRA** if surgery anticipated.
If obstruction suspected → **MAG3**; in peds with febrile UTIs/hydronephrosis → **VCUG**.
Treat **complications** (pyeloplasty for UPJ obstruction, stone management, UTI care); **no routine isthmus division**.
Long‑term follow‑up for infections, stones, BP, and renal function.

differentials.name: Crossed fused renal ectopia
differentials.hint: Fused kidneys on the **same side**; one ureter crosses midline to normal bladder insertion.

differentials.name: Pelvic kidney (simple ectopia)
differentials.hint: Low‑lying kidney **without** fusion; may mimic HSK on limited views.

differentials.name: Duplicated collecting system
differentials.hint: Can cause hydronephrosis/UTIs, but kidneys are separate; look for duplex ureter signs.

cases.stem: A 3‑year‑old boy has three febrile UTIs in 12 months and poor weight gain.
clues: US: bilateral hydronephrosis + midline parenchymal band
MAG3: delayed washout from renal pelvis
cases.teaching: Fusion and malrotation can kink the UPJ → poor drainage, stasis, infections. Manage based on drainage/function (often pyeloplasty if threatened).

cases.stem: A 16‑year‑old girl with short stature, webbed neck, and primary amenorrhea is evaluated for hypertension.
clues: Renal US: fused lower poles crossing the midline
cases.teaching: HSK is a classic renal anomaly in Turner (≈14–20%). Most are asymptomatic; screen for reflux/obstruction when clinically indicated.
